user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_drop:
```c
static int lfs_dir_drop(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_mdir_t *dir, lfs_mdir_t *tail) {
    // steal state
    int err = lfs_dir_getgstate(lfs, tail, &lfs->gdelta);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // steal tail
    lfs_pair_tole32(tail->tail);
    err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, dir, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_TAIL + tail->split, 0x3ff, 8), tail->tail}));
    lfs_pair_fromle32(tail->tail);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_dir_drop:
static int lfs_dir_getgstate(lfs_t *lfs, const lfs_mdir_t *dir,
        lfs_gstate_t *gstate) {
    lfs_gstate_t temp;
    lfs_stag_t res = lfs_dir_get(lfs, dir, LFS_MKTAG(0x7ff, 0, 0),
            LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_MOVESTATE, 0, sizeof(temp)), &temp);
    if (res < 0 && res != LFS_ERR_NOENT) {
        return res;
    }

    if (res != LFS_ERR_NOENT) {
        // xor together to find resulting gstate
        lfs_gstate_fromle32(&temp);
        lfs_gstate_xor(gstate, &temp);
    }

    return 0;
}
...
static inline void lfs_pair_tole32(lfs_block_t pair[2]) {
    pair[0] = lfs_tole32(pair[0]);
    pair[1] = lfs_tole32(pair[1]);
}
...
static int lfs_dir_commit(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_mdir_t *dir,
        const struct lfs_mattr *attrs, int attrcount) {
    int orphans = lfs_dir_orphaningcommit(lfs, dir, attrs, attrcount);
    if (orphans < 0) {
        return orphans;
    }

    if (orphans) {
        // make sure we've removed all orphans, this is a noop if there
        // are none, but if we had nested blocks failures we may have
        // created some
        int err = lfs_fs_deorphan(lfs, false);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return 0;
}
...
static inline void lfs_pair_fromle32(lfs_block_t pair[2]) {
    pair[0] = lfs_fromle32(pair[0]);
    pair[1] = lfs_fromle32(pair[1]);
}
...
#define LFS_MKATTRS(__VA_ARGS__) (structlfs_mattr[]){__VA_ARGS__},sizeof((structlfs_mattr[]){__VA_ARGS__})/sizeof(structlfs_mattr)
...
#define LFS_MKTAG(type, id, size) (((lfs_tag_t)(type)<<20)|((lfs_tag_t)(id)<<10)|(lfs_tag_t)(size))
...
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
typedef struct lfs_mdir {
    lfs_block_t pair[2];
    uint32_t rev;
    lfs_off_t off;
    uint32_t etag;
    uint16_t count;
    bool erased;
    bool split;
    lfs_block_t tail[2];
} lfs_mdir_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter variable is reassigned in lfs_dir_drop or in the shown related functions. The MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 forbids modifying parameter variables themselves (e.g., doing `lfs = ...`, `dir = ...`, or `tail = ...`), but allows modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter. In lfs_dir_drop: - lfs, dir, and tail are only used/read or used to access their pointee members (e.g., tail->tail, tail->split). - lfs_pair_tole32 and lfs_pair_fromle32 write to the elements of the array passed (pair[0], pair[1]) which are objects referenced by the pointer parameter — this is allowed by the rule. - lfs_dir_getgstate declares its dir parameter as const, so it cannot modify the pointed-to object; it only updates gstate. - lfs_dir_commit may modify the directory object pointed to by dir (permitted), but there is no reassignment of the dir pointer itself. Therefore there are no code fragments that appear to violate Rule 17.8 in the provided code.
